Fields.DialogueText: Kirov! Perhaps the streets of Leningrad are much louder than the swell of the sea, but for God's sake... for the sailors on board this vessel! Can you please bring the volume down?
Doveriyeeee my dolzhnyyyyy! Oh, Kapitan, it is for the sailors on board that I sing my song!
First Comrade Kirov...
God is but opiate of the masses, but music... music is true spirit. I fear the mood aboard this ship grows drearier as we speak...

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps additional deck duties will aid in absolving your bleak mood, Comrade.
Don't blow things out of proportion, Kirov. Just bring it down a notch before you sing away our position.
Mmm... perhaps we could use a little extra spirit aboard.

Fields.DialogueText: Take it easy, Kapitan... you know what they say, a man quick to his gun is a man quick with his gun, haha!
You got it, Kapitan. Sorry to stir you from your no doubt pleasurable dreams!
That's it, Kapitan! War is the worst time to stop singing.
Brandy, Kapitan? Maybe all you need is a little warmth to put the light back to your lantern.
I assure you my lantern is absent no light... and brandy on duty, Kirov? I find that hard to swallow, considering your rank.
Mmn... I find it hard not to swallow, Kapitan. Spare me from such hollow and meaningless terms as rank.
Why are you standing on the kitchen table? What are you doing? Kirov! You're...
*ALARM*
Morganas... all right, Kirov, let's see if you attack with the same vigor you sing.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Vecherinka nachinayetsya! Courage, Kapitan!
*sniff*
I didn't realize courage came at 100 proof.
@BATTLE
Well done! I'm pleasantly surprised at your ability to perform after a half-bottle of brandy.
I'm capable of many other pleasant performances after a healthy portion of brandy, Kapitan. Ha!
You certainly aren't lacking passion, Comrade. And, due to the bravado of your actions in battle, I'm willing to overlook your more... outlandish behavior.
Oh, Kapitan, the whole of cold and hungry Leningrad couldn't parallel your generosity...
Under one condition.
Nothing too improper, I presume?
Tell me, why were you standing on the kitchen table?
Don't worry about it, Kapitan. You wouldn't understand.
As the ranking captain of this ship, it is my duty to understand every operation aboard this vessel.
And here we go again with the rank, Kapitan. Those who prop themselves up on title always make me wonder what other things they might be compensating for...

Fields.MenuText: I suggest you learn to think before you speak, Comrade. I'll not have my position insulted again.
I assert my authority as captain only to find out more about the operations aboard this ship. I have nothing to compensate for.
Ha! Save it for the enemy, Kirov!

Fields.DialogueText: I feel another quip coming on...
Nothing to compensate for, huh, Kapitan?
Ah, Kapitan, just wait and see!
Excellent work recently, Kirov. I'm interested to see the extent of your ferocity.
Spasibo, Kapitan, but surviving the attacks of Rusalki scum is child's play compared to looking after five naughty younger sisters.
Five naughty younger sisters, huh?
Don't get any ideas, Kapitan! Besides... I'm the prettiest lady in the family anyway.
And most humble, clearly.
Ha! Aren't you quite the jokester today, Kapitan? Now, let's see...  I'm long overdue for a drink.
And you'll stay overdue...
Hey! My brandy! Give that bottle back!
Until you tell me what you were doing standing on the kitchen table...
*sigh* All right, Kapitan. I'll talk... I was seeing if I could hang decorations from the rafters.

Fields.MenuText: This is a cruiser, Kirov! Not a giant floating paint gallery.
Decorations? Comrade, I'm flattered, but my birthday is still a long way off.
Well why didn't you say something! This place could use a little pizazz.

Fields.DialogueText: *sigh* I hope you don't jump ship with the same haste you jump to conclusions, Kapitan.
You're a funny one, Kapitan... But I decorate for another event...
See, Kapitan! It was nothing to ever worry about. Now, be a darling and hand over the brandy...
And for what important upcoming event did you need to shift your focus to the mess decks?
Captain! Morgana ships approaching stern side!
Ah! Seems the enemy spares you from explanation again, Kirov. Positions everyone! Don't think I'll forget about this conversation.
@BATTLE
You never seem to disappoint, Kirov!
In more ways than you know, Kapitan.
Your deft maneuvering is a true gift to the men and women aboard this ship.
All right...
Which is why it pains me to ask this...
I had a feeling something like this was coming.
The decorations in the mess decks. Explain.
Ah, Kapitan. Fine, if you must really know, I'm trying to find the best room to host my show!

Fields.MenuText: Your show? Kirov, this is a cruiser, not a playhouse!
You're think you're going to perform a show for the men and women aboard this boat? I don't know I think you're capable of pulling that off.
Kirov... you can't be serious.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah! Just because we are at war, Kapitan, doesn't mean we have to pretend like we are already dead.
Supportive as always, I see.
Oh, Kapitan, we spend way too much time being serious aboard this ship.
Look to the bow, Kirov. Morganas. Sound the alarm, get into position! Push thoughts of whatever show you're imagining out of your head. War demands attention.
@BATTLE
You're a frustrating woman, Kirov...
Believe it or not, you're not the first person to say those words, Kapitan.
Your insubordination is a constant threat to order aboard this ship - and a thorn in my backside. Yet, I wish my crew fought fight with half the fury you do...
Ah, Kapitan, I've only ever been trying to help. And it's probably best if we avoid all conversations concerning thorns and backsides.
Very funny, Kirov. Your propensity for humor seems as vast as your skill in battle.
Muzzzzzyka yego prostoyyyy! Kapitan, it's simple. How can you expect the crew aboard this ship to perform without song in their hearts?

Fields.MenuText: Kirov, your whimsical solutions have no place in these hostile waters.
Kirov, are you really saying that you think song can motivate this rag-tag bunch of sleepy sailors?
Song? Right then, fetch me the scalpel! I'll cut these men open, you can sing a falsetto into their chests, and then we'll see if that makes any difference!

Fields.DialogueText: My home of Leningrad is as hostile as any waters, Kapitan. I fear I never would have survived without laughter and song.
Kapitan, you would be wise to listen to what I have to say.
You sound crazy! Kapitan, there's no reason to act so bull-headed!
All right then, Kirov... I'm willing to listen.
Kapitan, your crew is dying for something to give their minds a break from the war.
Perhaps we see things from a different perspective, Kirov. The crew is living because their minds are focused on the war.
*ALARM*
Seems the war has found it's way to us again. Into positions everyone! Pick up the pace!
Rah! Rusalki dogs!
@BATTLE
Kapitan, about our earlier conversation...
Another time perhaps, Kirov. I have an important radio call scheduled with Command. Keep an eye on deck, will you?
A radio call to Command? Kapitan, it's your duty to keep me informed of all matters aboard this ship. So tell me, Kapitan. Why the call to Command?

Fields.MenuText: Rank and status dictate my duties and what information is passed to my crew. I suggest you learn that, Kirov.
If I knew, I would tell you, Comrade. Be patient, I'll let you know as soon as I am done radioing out.
Keep your mind occupied with silly thoughts of opera and dancing. I have a ship to run, Kirov.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, Kapitan! Your talk of bureaucracy makes me sick. Go to the radio and leave me to the back already.
Ah, a good kapitan keeps his ship informed. Hopefully those overdressed bastards at Command send us good news.
Maybe it is you, Kapitan, who is absent song in their heart. I'd rather occupy my mind with thoughts of music than with thoughts of you.
Stay out of trouble, Kirov. I'll be back soon.
Take your time, please.
Damn! Rusalkis at the port! KAPITAN! Rah! Great... stubborn and deaf.
Kapitaaaaaaan! Enemyyyy ships approach Portside! Rusalki bastards! Come on, Kapitan...
*ALARM*
Aha! Perhaps there is song in your heart yet, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
Those last Morganas were stronger than I'd anticipated.
And yet, you stare death in the face with humor as boundless as the ocean. I'd wager your taunts hurt worse than any wounds the Morganas could inflict.
Leningrad is a cold place to call home, Kapitan. I learned to laugh through the bloodshed a long time ago. Come, take a load off, Kapitan. Have a brandy...
I'm fine, Kirov. But listen, I owe you an apology...
An apology? Did you hit your head against the deck floor, Kapitan? Are the skies raining money? Do go on, darling. Maybe it's more close calls that we need!
Very funny, Comrade. Listen, in the past I've given you a hard time about your loud... er... powerful, and constant, singing.
Mmm, Kapitan. Your flattery is making me blush. Go on...
And well, if it wasn't for your voice... your song, we may very well have been reduced to a relic on the ocean floor.
Finally, Kapitan! You're starting to see the benefits of having a woman like me around...

Fields.MenuText: And I'm still trying to figure out whether it's a curse or a blessing...
Perhaps I have been overly doubtful, Kirov. You have a lot to learn, but I'm glad to have you aboard.
Oh, how truly lucky I am.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, that depends on you, Kapitan. Never mess with a lady from Leningrad...
Finally, Kapitan! You learn to sing... your words are music to my ears!
You're alive aren't you, Kapitan?
So, Kapitan, are you ready to admit the necessity of song aboard this ship yet?
Kirov, we have more urgent matters to attend to. My radio call to command...
Save it, Kapitan! Rusalki bastards are back already! Look stern-side!
@BATTLE
The seas continue to run red and black with blood and oil.
Allied ships nearby have fallen victim to these hostile waters.
Rah! Rusalki bastards!
We've got another one. Sounds like they've been hit, but they're holding on...
You have a terrible poker face, Kapitan. There's a twitch in your eye that tells me there's more to this story...
Command thinks there may be a Morgana fleet loose in the waters, but no one can get a location.
An entire fleet, and no one can get a location? Maybe those press suited bastards at Command ought to get their heads out of their asses!

Fields.MenuText: Watch your tongue, Kirov. Those are highly decorated officers you're talking about.
Hate to admit it, but I'm thinking the same thing. Those bastards!
Never mind Command. We have urgent matters to attend to.

Fields.DialogueText: Highly decorated officers that probably know nothing turret fire, or the thrum of a cruiser's engine during battle.
Oh, Kapitan, I think you are the one who's finally speaking sensibly. Keep talking like that, and I might begin to like you.
Exactly ...  now, where did I put that brandy bottle?
Regardless, the threat is what matters.
It was the voices of the great Russian opera singers that kept me vigilant in the hardened streets of Leningrad, taking care of my sisters.
A heart-touching tale you can sing of another time. Get into position, Comrade.
Aye, Kapitan!
Damn! Looks like our departure is delayed. Enemy ships on the horizon! Prepare yourself, Comrade!
@BATTLE
That means I don't want to hear any mention of fantastical operas and shows for the time being. We need to be extra vigilant. We sail east to aid our allies.
We may not see eye to eye on everything, Kirov, but I can't deny that we're working well together.
Teamwork keeps us alive in these waters.
Something tells me you're about to try and make a point.
If you really want to motivate this crew to work better, maybe we have to practice working as a team more.
You're absolutely right, and right now, this team needs to sail east. I've heard that our damaged ally is a high ranking officer.
Ha! That explains the damage. Their gloved hands were probably too soft to man the turrets.
Comrade! Set coordinates to go east.
Coordinates already set, Kapitan. It's obvious we need to promote communication and teamwork between the sailors on this boat. And I know how we can...

Fields.MenuText: Let me guess - an opera?
Okay, Comrade, you have five minutes. Let me hear it.
We have a strict protocol to follow.

Fields.DialogueText: What a great idea, Kapitan! You can help me write it.
Five minutes, huh Kapitan? How efficient you think I am.
Kapitan! The damn Rusalkis show more courage than you!
Fine, Kirov. I'm willing to listen, but I'm not making any promises.
Kapitan, all this death and war. It's draining. It's draining on the mind, on the spirit, on the muscles, on the s...
All right, All right, get to the point, Comrade.
The crew need something to remind them of the joys of life.
Yes, yes, I know you want to put on a show.
Kapitan, with respect, I've survived the cold, gang-ridden streets of Leningrad, and proven myself through countless victories in these waters.
Go on...
How will you ever know what benefit that silly show could have if you never let me explain?
I'll think about that. For now, look sharp, Kirov. Enemy ships fast approaching towards the bow. Keep us alive, and I'll hear more of your plans.
@BATTLE
I've kept us alive so far, Kapitan! And since I've kept my end of the bargain...
Part of me wishes we would have sunk. But I'm true to my word - tell me of your silly show. Quickly. We draw nearer to ally coordinates as I speak.
Well, first off, Kapitan, I prefer to call it an opera, or a play. Anything but that "silly" show.
Explain further, Comrade. Only then can we decide upon proper terminology.
Uh! I swear you're more stubborn than the street dogs of Leningrad, Kapitan.
Get on with your pitch, Kirov.
Training the men and women aboard this ship in the fine craft of opera and drama will allow them to work together as a team. It will allow them to hone all the essential battle skills.
Really?
Discipline and order, attack and poise. How to think quickly and in the moment.
Hm...
Opera will allow their minds a reprieve from the constant stresses of this damn war. Your people will be refreshed for battle, Kapitan.
I think I'm starting to see what you mean.
But we can't approach this with half a heart. Will you help me set this up, Kapitan? For the crew? For me...

Fields.MenuText: I don't know, Kirov. My attention is already fully focused on the safety of this crew. Plus, if command we're to find out about something like this...
Comrade, I have a ship to run. I think the sailors on this ship will get much more out of hardwork and dedication than they will from prancing around onstage like a swan.
Comrade, it sounds like a good idea. I'll see what I can do.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, Kapitan! Screw those saps in Command. It is for the safety of this crew that I go to the great lengths of trying to get this through your thick skull!
You are a street dog, Kapitan. A stubborn street dog. Why can't you see that your crew needs this?
Are you serious, Kapitan?
WIll you help me?
Captain! Morgana ships spotted starboard, fast approaching!
Damn! No time, Kirov! Get into position!
@BATTLE
Seems the aggression of the eastern seas is more than a rumor. We're coming up on ally coordinates now, so keep your eyes peeled.
No sign of our allies, Kapitan. The waters are quiet, but something seems fishy.
We're in the ocean, Comrade. I couldn't think of a fishier place.
Ah, so you do have a sense of humor, Kapitan! Although, you certainly choose to show it at a strange time.
Okay, we're coming up on the exact coordinates now...
Be careful, Kapitan. Dindreeeee zek smerti...

Fields.MenuText: Thanks, Comrade. But I assure you, I know what I'm doing.
The tone of your song worries me, Comrade. What do you think?
Shh! You'll sing the enemy right to the stern!

Fields.DialogueText: Da, just as you've assured me so many times in the past. Tell me, Kapitan, do your assurances come so naturally because of your propensity to be such an ass?
Ah, even asking for my opinion now, huh Kapitan? You've matured so much already!
I fear the enemy may already be near, Kapitan.
I'll radio Command. They should have a grasp on the situation...
Pft! Please, Kapitan, don't bet on it. There's a tingle in my throat that tells me danger is riding on the surf.  We should leave before it's too late.
Now is not the time for superstitious paranoia.
Kapitan, stop fantasizing over the tackily-dressed bureaucrats in Command and their awards, and think for one second! We're sailing right into a trap.
We're staying until further word from Command. It's going to be fine.
Well if you're so sure then, Kapitan, make me a bet. If we get ambushed, and we live... you'll talk to the crew about my opera.
And what do I get out of it? If there's no ambush...
Seems like we'll never know, Kapitan. Look towards the horizon. Rusalkis! Bastards are coming from all directions!
Damn! Get into positions, people. Looks like we've got a whole navy headed towards us. You're sharp Kirov. Don't let me down, Comrade.
@BATTLE
Kirov, it seems you were right about that ambush.
Maybe next time you'll know to listen to what I have to say.
Can it, Kirov! This is no time.
Rusalki dogs approaching starboard, Kapitan. Should we stay and fight, or try and hightail it out of here?

Fields.MenuText: What do you take me for? I may be stubborn, but I've never been one to flee from battle!
We've sailed right into the wasp's nest, Comrade. Now we need to get the hell out of here!
Wet your lips for a victory brandy, Kirov. We stay and fight.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah! Spoken like a true kapitan.
Damn! Rusalki ships approaching from the north, too. Seems our options grow more limited still, Kapitan...
Better words have never left your mouth, Kapitan! As long as there's brandy on the shelf, we will live to fight another day!
If - or rather, when - we make it out of this alive, you're helping me with that silly show!
Is that an order? Giving orders to the higher-ups now?
Damn your ranking system, Kapitan! Death knows no hierarchy...
Keep us alive again, and fine, I'll help you.
@BATTLE
Get into position, Kirov! We need to push the hell out of here before any more Morganas show up.
Couldn't agree more, Kapitan. Besides, we have work to do as soon as we reach safer waters...
Good point, Comrade. The equipment and ammo stores need to be rechecked as soon as possible, and the deck needs a good eye over.
And?

Fields.MenuText: And what? That's the checklist...
Ah, the celebratory brandy, how could I have forgotten?!
... The opera. I'm not getting out of this one, am I Comrade?

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan, you seem much too full of life to be this forgetful already...
Ah, a Kapitan after my own heart. Da, brandy. But you're forgetting something else...
Mezzznich stubbooo! You may escape the weak traps of the Rusalkis, Kapitan, but you'll never escape my snares!
All right, Kirov. A good captain knows when to give into incentives and motivations. I'll speak to the crew about the play.
Oh, Kapitan! You grow wiser each day you're on stuck on this ship with me.
Must be all the wisdom, then, that this constant headache stems from. Tell me, Kirov, what's the name of the opera the crew will attempt to perform?
Kapitan, Kapitan, don't worry about that, just yet. I know you're used to rushing to the finish, but we need to take baby steps here.
Spare me, Kirov.
Right, well the first thing we need to do, then, is find three leading actors. Three sailors you think have star potential.
Why not just have a look at the three highest ranking officers in the roster?
Oh, I fear you'll learn nothing from the past! Just find me three people you think might be interested in taking on a challenge.
Captain! Enemy ships spotted approaching from the bow!
Seems we may not be able to break for safer waters yet, Kapitan...
@BATTLE
Oh, all these battles makes me thirsty. To the kitchen!
I'm past the point of trying to keep you from your brandy, Comrade.
How wise you are, Kapitan. Sounds like I've trained you right.
Trained? Am I a dog to you?
Right, Kapitan, you're a street dog. Now, come have a drink with me...

Fields.MenuText: That's enough, Kirov! You may be a hell of fighter, but I'm the ship's captain, and you will learn to respect me.
Is that right, Kirov? Do any of us truly act as more than animals?
Kirov, you're hardly aware of how much of an animal I can be.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan, I respect you greatly! I tease only to lighten the mood.
Kapitan! Where is your mind going?
Ho ho, aren't you confident, Kapitan?
Now, get ready, Kapitan. Training for the opera begins in three, two, ahem ... Odin!
Hold that thought, Kirov! Morganas.
Training has starrrrrted, Kapitan! Get angry! Feel the roar of the sea, and let it emanate in your heart and head...
Kirov?
Imagine your rage as a sound! Feel it in your ears and throat!
Kirov! Not now. Get into position!
Hold onto that sound, Kapitan! Hold onto that sound and survive this battle!
Rahhh!
@BATTLE
RAHHH! Morganas! This... is ONE CRUISER ...YOU'LL REGRET MESSING WITH!
Ah ha! You're really feeling it now, Kapitan! You've got the song in your heart.
AHHH!
All right, all right, Kapitan. Calm down. Have a brandy.
Kirov, I feel kind of... invincible right now!
All the great singers of Russia know that. Now, Kapitan, now we need to make the crew feel the same passion you do.

Fields.MenuText: Sign me up! I'm sold! I could sing the command out loud!
I'm still not sure, Comrade. How can we stay alert if our efforts are focused elsewhere?
You're a fine motivator, Kirov. I only hope the crew will take to your instruction as I did.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, Kapitan! There's a voltage in your voice, an exhilarating fire in your cheeks!
Sound and dance only sharpen the attention, Kapitan.
Kapitan, don't play with me. I need at least a carafe of fine brandy before looking to ride that wave.
Ready to commit, Kapitan?
I can't believe I'm saying this, but I've already starting scouting for star performers.
Admirable!
Damn. Off the starboard beam, Kirov. Looks like I'll have to postpone auditions.
What?! Rah! Rusalki dogs! Remember the passion, Kapitan! Smerrrrtii Iyut!
@BATTLE
Good work, Kapitan! I could see opera in your eyes when their cruiser burst into flames!
Kapitan! Any news?
Judging by the glass in your hand, I'd guess there are still a few bottles of brandy aboard... but the radio is still haywire.
Boo hoo! We cannot talk to Command. Gasp! I am shattered... but I was actually referring to the actors, Kapitan. Any talent scouting news?

Fields.MenuText: Well, excuse me for bringing urgent operations information to your attention. From now on I'll stick to current events dealing strictly with fantasy land!
Kirov, I'm willing to play ball here, but your opera comes second to the safety of this ship.
I'm working on it! Is impatience also a common trait for girls from Leningrad?

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan, don't misinterpret my meaning. I do know those things are important.
I couldn't agree more, Kapitan. Perhaps I should add multitasking to our opera training regimen?
Ha! A Leningrad girl knows what she wants, and when she wants to have it. Hardly a crime.
All right, I get it, Comrade. Actually, I did happen to walk by the showers on the way back from the radio room. I heard one of the officers singing.
You were doing what, Kapitan?!
I stopped outside the door to listen. His voice was beautiful! I think we found one of the performers for this opera.
Well, Kapitan... I'm not sure I agree with your decision to lurk outside the showers, but good work!
Do you have a name for this opera, for your show?
No name yet, Kapitan. Hmm... Blin! A shape in the fog to starboard.
Sure, sure. Well, what's the show about?
You made your point! Safety first... Maybe you'll get to hear about the show if we live.
@BATTLE
Ah! Rusalki bastards blend right into the fog.
At ease, Comrade. I think that was the last one, for now. Damn equipment is still fuzzed though. We're just going to have to push out of this weather.
And on with the show! Kapitan, I'm going to need some metal forks, empty shell casings, laundry soap boxes, and empty shoe polish tins. Mission two begins now!
Come on, Kirov, do you know how long it's going to take to get all that stuff? What could you possibly be using it for?
The time has come to make a set, Kapitan. How are we supposed to sway the audience with a blank stage? Burning emotion doesn't come from a blank canvas, Kapitan!

Fields.MenuText: Aha! Surely you can't make props, much less a set, out of that trash heap inventory?
Can you really build something of worth from this list, Comrade? I'd be impressed!
Maybe a blank canvas would be better. You know, uh, keep the focus on the performers.

Fields.DialogueText: You would be surprised, Kapitan, of what miracles I can work with my hands.
It's nothing, Kapitan. Really! Just another skill you can take home at the end of this pitiful war.
Are you this lazy in all aspects of life, Kapitan? Where's the drive?!
Excuse me for being frank, but this whole thing feels arbitrary, Kirov.
Arbitrary? I have poverty to thank for my resourcefulness. Building this set, it's going to show you and the crew the meaning of using every piece of what you have.
Well, the radio is still on the crackle. Fine, I'll set the crew to the task.
You're a sharp one, Kapitan. Your crew is going to learn the value of resources - a useful skill in any battle.
I hope you're right Kirov, but we'll have to worry about that later. Morgana's approaching at the stern. You know the drill, Kirov...
@BATTLE
These waters aren't safe. We need to get out of here. If only this radio were actually working!
There's no sense in worrying about the things you can't fix, Kapitan. Cheer up! Help me finish this brandy and tell me some good news.
Well, Comrade, I've set the crew to task. Now, we'll just have to wait and see what they drudge up. But Kirov, how am I supposed to build a set for a play I don't even know the name of!?
I suppose it is about time to tell you what the opera is about...
I'd say it's well past time. And look, why don't you tell me in the radio room. I'm going to try and get that damn thing to work one more time...
Here Kapitan, take this notebook with you. The opera is in here.
Act One. Two hearts pine for the same woman. Oh for god's sake, Kirov. Don't tell me you expect the crew to perform a romance...
Kapitan! Keep reading. I think you'll find there's more to the story. Besides, has a sailor ever had a stronger motivator than the heart of a woman?

Fields.MenuText: No, and nor has a sailor ever had a greater danger!
Yes, that semi-important thing, you know ...  the sailor's own life.
Hmph! I'd like to meet that sailor...

Fields.DialogueText: Haha, Kapitan! Perhaps you do have more... "battle" experience than I expected.
Oh, Kapitan... what is a man's life without the love of a woman?
Have you met a sailor?
Fine. I'll take a look through the book if I get a chance...
*BOOM*
Damn! Looks like that might not be for a while. Positions everyone!
@BATTLE
Good work, Comrade. Keep your eyes on deck. I'll going to the radio room, before we have any other unfortunate interruptions.
Kapitan! Don't forget the notebook...
Right, how could I have left the script for a romance opera behind? There is no genre that better motivates a naval commander than romance.
Okay, I don't understand. Why does Dimitri try to sway Vera away from Vadim? It's obvious Vadim has true feelings for her, and yet Dimitri swoons after her, despite their friendship...
So you have found the time to read through the script? Many find intellect an attractive trait.
Uh, yes, well, captains always needs to act with intellect. I just don't get it though, Vera's family offers support to both men, and Dimitri...
Da, Kapitan?
Ah! It just seems so obvious that he's in it for the Budush family money!
Kapitan, I thought this story was going to be just an emotional, womanly sap story. And now look at you! You're practically enraptured!

Fields.MenuText: Okay, you got me. I'll admit it, Shakespeare, you've crafted a really engaging work.
Listen, Comrade, I'm just trying to iron out the facts. I've made a commitment to see this thing through, and, unfortunately in this case, I always keep my word.
I just can't put this down, Kirov! Who does Vera choose?

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan! Muzkha belye!!! Kapitan, your kind words warm my heart like a glass of good brandy.
I'm humbled by your attempt to cover up your true feelings. People who don't fear sentiment are great lovers...
You expect me to give it away, Kapitan? Never!
Looks like you're going to just have to keep reading, Kapitan.
Oh, and we finished finding the building materials for the set. You'll never believe it, but one of the sailors found a repair kit for the radio...
Kapitan! You fixed the radio? That's great!
I must say, Kirov... I doubted the benefit of this opera training... or rehearsal... or whatever.
And?
But so far it has been-
*BOOM*
Ah! Look ahead towards that break in the fog Does that look like...
One hell of a large fleet, Kapitan. Sing with me! Smeerrrti Vano!
...RAHHH!
@BATTLE
Victory!
Captain! Command is on the radio. They say it's urgent.
Everything all right, Kapitan? What joyous and useful information did the gentle pencil pushers in Command bestow upon us this time?
There's a trail of sunken ships and incinerated cruiser parts floating east of here. The trail leads right towards our coordinates.
There's no choice in war, Kapitan. Only a fool would fear what cannot be escaped.
I feel much like Vadim. Waiting for the cold steel tip of Dimitri's blade, smiling in the sour face of betrayal.
Kapitan! That passion! No ship in the ocean that could topple that. The crew needs to feel that.
And perhaps one day they will, but I have to act rationally here, Kirov.
Brandy, Kapitan?
Suspend all other operations. We push west as fast as this cruiser can move.
Do all other operations include the opera?

Fields.MenuText: Did I stutter, Kirov? There may be some value in this whole crazy thing we're doing, but there's no telling what kind of enemy we're dealing with here.
Circumstances are trying, Kirov, but I suppose we could consider a shift system for the time being.
Listen, I want to see this story played out just as badly as you do, but we need to be alive for that to happen.

Fields.DialogueText: Just like there's no telling the power we will have in these waters, with a crew full of the rage and fury of tragedy! We've made it this far, Kapitan.
You're getting so good at this. Admirable Kapitan, productive stage manager!
Fight with passion, Kapitan! And we will live to sing another day.
We just don't have time, Kirov. Get into position. We sail west.
Not so fast, Kapitan. Seems danger lurks in every drop of these waters. Rusalkis astern!
@BATTLE
It appears I might already be late for my appointment...
Appointment, Kirov?
With my dearest friend - brandy! You two should spend more time together.
Restrict your appetite, Kirov. We're in dangerous waters now. Keep sailing west, and I'm going to make one more call out to Command and see about the impending danger.
You're a funny one, Kapitan. Before you go... can I have my notebook back?

Fields.MenuText: Thanks for taking this off my hands. It was just sitting there...
Actually, you wouldn't mind if I held onto this for a bit longer, would you?
Notebook? Oh yeah, I'd, uh, have to find it first, wouldn't take too long...

Fields.DialogueText: Sitting there doing nothing in your open palms? Kapitan, you don't have to pretend like the story doesn't intrigue you.
Perhaps I should start charging you a rental fee, Kapitan!
Do you tell white lies to all your friends, Kapitan?
Listen, I need to stay focused. If I don't have something to occupy my mind down, I could doze off. It's probably better I take the notebook.
Right, Kapitan! Of course, we wouldn't want you to doze off in the midst of imminent death.
Keep an eye on the deck...
That's where I keep my brandy! Oh, and Kapitan...
Hm?
Your training is almost complete - the opera is near ready.
War is an unfortunate setting to have dreams, Kirov. I'll be back in a little while.
Kapitan... Zedzaaaa Okennnaa! Damn! Rusalkis by the bow! Kaaaaaaapitan!
@BATTLE
Kapitan, your face is whiter than a Leningrad winter.
I've just spoken to command, Kirov.
One day, I'd love to light that radio on fire...
Another ally ship has gone down. A massive Morgana fleet with major destructive capabilities is making a beeline for us.
Well, hey! There's a new situation...
Command has instructed us to attempt surrender when we come into contact with the fleet.
Surrender? There's not surrender against Morganas, Kapitan!

Fields.MenuText: Surrender could be the most noble option if we're severely outnumbered.
I would rather drown a hundred-year death than surrender, Kirov.
I have strict orders to follow any and all instruction from Command, Kirov.

Fields.DialogueText: The thought makes me sick, Kapitan.
Kapitan! Never have your words made you seem more admirable. You are truly worthy of your title.
After all Command has put us through? You're still blindly trusting these... chess players in oversized military jackets?
You're right. It must be some kind of mistake. Even if it isn't, surrender makes no sense. Are they testing us?!
Oh, Kapitan, your words are as sweet as brandy. Remember, there's no sense fearing what you can't avoid. We've have nothing to lose.
Which reminds me - is that why Vera chose to wed herself off to Dimitri? She had to have known Dimitri killed Vadim.
Ah, so you're almost to the end of the story now, Kapitan? Perhaps she was a woman with nothing to lose... Damn! Kapitan, enemy ships at the starboard!
Perhaps Vera should have done something earlier...
@BATTLE
Kirov! Double check all the weapons aboard this ship, take stock of ammo, medical supplies, explosives... everything!
Ah! Kapitan, this is so exciting!
We're going to be ready for these Morgana vermin. When the moment comes, we won't be like Vera, forced to surrender, wedding herself to the enemy...
Kapitan, you've become so eloquent recently. I'm so proud!
Kirov! I need to speak with you now, in my office!
Kapitan, what matter is so urgent you need to pull me away from our endless list of preparations?
You need to change the ending...
You finished the story, Kapitan?
Dimitri... ah! How can you have him be the one who gets what he wants in the story? He kills all of Vera's family!
Would you have me change it into a romance?
How is this tragedy, ending in so much death, supposed to motivate our crew?
Tragedy is a cold reality that is never far off, Kapitan. Acknowledging that fact is an advantage in battle. Think of what the crew has learned already, Kapitan!
They have seemed particularly motivated recently...
Kapitan, we are a living crew amongst a sea of dead allies. Your crew has learned to be resourceful, motivated, focused...
I see your point. Let's hope that follows through in the battle ahead.
Seems the first waves of battle are already upon us. Get ready, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Ah ha! Rusalki dogs could never scare me.
I fear the worst is yet to come.
Kapitan, the crew still has things left to learn, but there's simply not enough time to train them for the whole opera. What should we do, Kapitan?

Fields.MenuText: I really wanted to see this through, but war demands our focus.
Passion's what it's all about, right? We don't have to do the whole play, just so long as we can ignite that flame.
I'm no quitter, Kirov. We're going to see to this thing through.

Fields.DialogueText: That's your solution, Kapitan? Seems like we could do at least a little better than giving up!
I love your thinking, Kapitan! They may sing only one lyric, but they're going to shake the seas!
If you insist, Kapitan... But the training will be rough for an entire production. I worry for the crew's sanity!
All right Comrade, I've come to a decision. You'll train the crew to perform one song. Dimitri's Ode to Power.
A wise musical choice, Kapitan.
Ah, here the crew approaches now.
And after their courageous voices sail over the waves of the sea, striking fear into those Rusalki cowards, then Kapitan - I'll bring out one of my most treasured possessions.
I only pray that's the outcome. And what treasure is that? Is there a sequel to this masterpiece?
Ah ha! Not yet, Kapitan...
Perhaps we could both have a hand in writing it.
Perhaps, Kapitan. The treasure I speak of is my family's best brandy.
I don't know...
Perhaps, if we live to sing off the bow another day, you'll share my bottle? Surely, you wouldn't let a girl drink alone?

Fields.MenuText: Thanks, Kirov, but I'm not much of a drinker. My focus is on my crew and the war only.
We'll see how my mood fares after the battle.
Strange, you've never seemed to have a problem drinking alone in the past.

Fields.DialogueText: Shame, Kapitan... although, there's a part of me that is curious about what that focus feels like.
When we win, your mood will be one of elation, no doubt.
Perhaps I'm just feeling even more social than usual.
I guess we'll just have to see about that drink after these men and women show us what kind of music they're capable of. Sailors! Let's hear it.
"Daaaannngggeerr Danggger!"
Ow! My ears. We have more work than we thought.
We just need a little bit of time. Okay, boys and girls! Let's hear it again!
*ALARM*
Morgana ships astern. Get into position, people!
And don't stop singing! Feel the music in your heart and hands!
@BATTLE
That was a small fleet, Kapitan. What did you make of those Rusalkis?
Looked like scout ships, Kirov. Something big is definitely headed our way.
*The chorus of sailors begins to sing...*
Let's hear it again, crew! Remember... powerful, but focused.
"Fiiiiirrrrree!"
Stop! Stop! Kirov, I don't know about this. This noise is likely to kill us long before any Morgana ships do.
That's just it! This is no time to give up, Kapitan. Listen, the crew might not be cut for the stage of the Globe Theatre, but their voices are grating and deadly!
What?
Let's hear it!
"IRRROOOONNN!"
The crew might not perform this entire production, or even one song, but listen to the passion in that hideous chorus!
That's one way to put it...
The grating and irritating quality of that sound is sure enough to strike fear and confusion into the hearts of any enemy.
Son of a bitch, Kirov, you're right!
So we didn't finish the show! The crew received the training they needed. We're ready for anything, Kapitan.
Yes, we are!

Fields.MenuText: I'm ready to learn all about her.
She's a hard worker, a true friend, and one hell of a sailor.

Fields.DialogueText: *The sailors sing as they fight...*
